docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Muscle turns to fat when you stop working out. THE FACTS -- As summer heats up and Americans flock to the shores to bare their beach muscles, those of us whose gym memberships collected dust last winter or expired months ago may be left with physiques that went from firm to flabby. So did all those muscles simply melt to fat from more time on the couch and less at the sports club?
docs.snippet: Will all those muscles simply melt to fat from more time on the couch and less at the sports club?

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing in the Hippocratic Oath that tells doctors what to do when they make a mistake with a patient. Nor is there much on this subject in medical school curriculums or in residency training programs. But there should be.

headline.main: Learning Words They Rarely Teach in Medical School: 'I'm Sorry'

docs.snippet: There is nothing in the Hippocratic Oath that tells doctors what to do when they make a mistake with a patient. But there should be.

docs.lead_paragraph: Prayer from a distance -- whether Christian, Muslim, Jewish or Buddhist -- did not significantly improve the outcome for common elective cardiac procedures performed on a group 737 patients, a new study reports. The research, published July 16 in Lancet, also examined the effectiveness of bedside music, imagery and MIT therapy, a touching technique that was found effective by some measures.

headline.main: A Prayer for the Heart Patient: Does It Help?

docs.snippet: Prayer from a distance did not significantly improve the outcome for common elective cardiac procedures performed on a group 737 patients, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: Female identical twins, even when raised together, differ significantly in health status depending on the economic class they attain as adults, according to research published yesterday in Public Library of Science Medicine. In a survey of 308 twin pairs, working-class women had higher blood pressure and higher cholesterol than their professional twins, and their estimates of their own health were consistently lower than those of their more affluent sisters.

headline.main: In Gauging Twins' Health, Follow the Money

docs.snippet: Female identical twins, even when raised together, differ significantly in health status depending on the economic class they attain as adults, according to a new study.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an emergency room at a Finnish hospital, a man sprawled unconscious on an operating table as surgeons labored to reattach the hand he had lost hours earlier while chopping wood. Medical miracles take many forms, but few are as vivid and immediate as this: As the tiny blood vessels were sutured back together, the patient's hand flushed from porcelain to pink. The delicate tendons of the palm revived, and the skin's granite glaze began to soften.
docs.snippet: A microsurgeon may soon perform the first face transplant. Is she giving people back a part of themselves or rushing a risky surgery?

multimedia.credit: While the dangers include life-threatening infections and the rejection of the transplant by the patient's immune system, the operation may be the only way to restore the semblance of a normal face.
multimedia.caption: Far Beyond Skin Grafts

legacy.MultimediaSummary3: While the dangers include life-threatening infections and the rejection of the transplant by the patient's immune system, the operation may be the only way to restore the semblance of a normal face.

docs.lead_paragraph: At least for some kinds of surgery, you are never too old. A study published last week found that age was not a factor in predicting whether the patient would suffer complications from head and neck surgery.

headline.main: For Head and Neck Surgery, It's Never Too Late

docs.snippet: A study found that age was not a factor in predicting whether the patient would suffer complications from head and neck surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who do not exercise enough may have a new explanation in the weather. A new study finds that people in cool, dry climates spend more time exercising than those who live where it is hot and humid. Using data from a telephone survey conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, researchers correlated information about exercise with weather reports from 255 weather stations in the United States and Puerto Rico to figure out what percentage of people in each region met the C.D.C. exercise recommendations -- 30 minutes of moderate physical activity 5 to 7 days a week or 20 minutes of vigorous physical activity 3 to 7 days a week.

headline.main: Climate May Strongly Influence Exercise Habits

docs.snippet: A new study finds that people in cool, dry climates spend more time exercising than those who live where it is hot and humid.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two Chinese exercise techniques -- the ancient martial art of tai chi and exercising by walking on cobblestones -- may improve the balance of older people and help prevent falls, according to two new studies. In the tai chi study, published in the July issue of The Journal of Advanced Nursing, 59 men and women with an average age of 78 were divided into two groups, one participating in a 12-week tai chi course, the other maintaining its usual activities without exercise classes.

headline.main: 2 Exercises Help Older People Stay on Their Feet

docs.snippet: Two Chinese exercise techniques may improve the balance of older people and help prevent falls, according to two new studies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Summer has long been a time of renewed efforts to lose excess pounds that are hard to hide under skimpy hot-weather clothing. And to be sure, some people (rarely those significantly overweight) manage to shed 5 or even 10 pounds before the Fourth of July. But having just driven from New York to Minnesota and back, at every rest stop I saw evidence of what health experts are calling a national crisis -- an epidemic of obesity, especially life-limiting, health-robbing morbid obesity.

headline.main: Magic Pill for Dieting? Wait for It on the Treadmill

docs.snippet: Weighing the options  exercise, surgery, medication  for losing weight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Decades ago, in the 1930's, when doctors routinely did autopsies, they noticed something strange. Inside the bones, deep in the marrow, people had grown fat cells. And the older they got, the more their bones were filling with fat. ''You start out with basically zero fat,'' said Dr. Jeffrey Gimble of the Pennington Biomedical Research Center in Baton Rouge, La. ''At the time of birth, you have just a little bit of fat in the bones of your fingertips.''

headline.main: What's Inside Those Old Bones? With Osteoporosis, It Seems to Be Fat

docs.snippet: Scientists are finding that in osteoporosis, bone cavities that everyone thought were just empty spaces are actually crammed with fat.

multimedia.credit: Healthy bone consists of many thick, closely linked fibers called trabeculae. Inosteoporotic bones, fat and fibrous tissue replace much of the trabeculae.
multimedia.caption: A Tale of Two Wrists

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Healthy bone consists of many thick, closely linked fibers called trabeculae. Inosteoporotic bones, fat and fibrous tissue replace much of the trabeculae.
